He mocked us for our MT average (57%), is condescending when it comes to answering questions, and clowns us when we don't know how to code certain concepts which he gave little no to guidance on. Also, half the course was boring yap abt his DSA drawings, and slides with typos
read textbook + self study > going to lecture. save your time transitting and spending 1 hour in lecture

This prof is very unorganized, there is miscommunication between the prof and the TA's, we didn't get our first assignment until a month and a half into the semester. Shermer just reads off the slides and barely shows any coding. Avoid this prof if you actually want to learn something in this course.

Tom is a pretty understanding and good prof, as he understants the struggle of remote learning and mental health. However, the assignments for his class are very difficult (theres 6) and requires the ENTIRE week to work on if you dont have a strong understanding in C++. His midterm was terrible but he made the final fairly easier for students.

Tom is very approachable for any questions over email/piazza and I appreciate that he has a sense of humour and understands that we have lives outside of school (reasonable deadlines + difficulty, etc.) Also, changing the grading criteria to favour assignments (60%) helped with the online format. The final (30%) was of a fair difficulty. Great guy!
Extremely disinterested in online courses, practically reads verbatim off the slides. Gives no information about tests

Lectures are extremely dull but are useful. Assignments are good in length and difficulty. However, he does try to cover a lot of materials. Exams contain no surprises. He really knows the subject matter, but I feel he doesn't really care too much whether students could understand his delivery. Overall not the best teacher, but far from the worst.

I have never experienced a teacher this bad in my life. How do you teach computer science without ever demonstrating a single program? No source code or example programs, only bits of pseudo code on the slides. His lectures are so dull I can barely get through the videos. His teaching leaves me more confused than I was before this class.

I think Tom is very passionate about computer science as a subject, CMPT 225 just doesn't quite scratch the itch for him in terms of its content richness so he didn't seem very lively at lectures. He's happy to explain topics to you that you don't understand, and an overall good professor. I'm sure he's great for higher level courses.
Decent Prof. Lectures are somewhat boring. Assignments and tests are fair. Nothing crazy.
He was okay. Most of the coursework was manageable.

Even when dealing with family problems during the semester, Geoffrey still finds a way to cater to students before exams and assignment due dates with extra office hours. He's the type of professor that is more than willing to explain things again during office hours if you're stuck on an assignment or don't understand a concept. Huge respect!

Assignments and exams are tough but he is there for you .If in doubt, ask him questions via E-mail, attend office hours. Stays well over his office hours if students need help. He is the kind of professor we need in our department.

Geoff delivers good lectures and is helpful in his office hours. His assignments are above average difficulty (compared to John Edgar's which are viewable online). His exams are quite difficult and he gives you no way to prepare for them. Overall, he teaches well with kind of hard assignments, but asks unreasonably difficult questions on the exam.
Assignments are ok but final is hard. Don't expect that he will be grading on a curve
Good teaching skill but the final is hard for this semester. One of my friend said it was easy last year.
Geoff is a very clear lecturer. He also gives good help in his office hours. He is a difficult professor though (tough tests and assignments). He'll teach you well, but he'll expect a lot out of you.

Geoff is a very good professor. He's clear in lecture and in his expectations for what you should know. He's pretty quick to help you via E-mail too. His exams and assignments are neither super difficult not easy, they were pretty reasonable in my opinion.

He is a really nice person. USE HIE OFFICE HOUR, it will help you a lot. Do the assignment ASAP and ask any question you don't know. midterm and final are ok. Do all the lecture note's questions, that is the key to pass this class.
Helpful when asked. Assignment criteria is clear. Little feedback for marks. Rarely open to understanding an answer from another point of view. Lectures are often dull.

Very amicable and helpful in one-on-one interactions, especially during office hours. However, lectures can get somewhat monotonous, which might just be a reflection of the course material. Make sure to clarify questions during exams because some of them can be worded ambiguously.

He has been really helpful during office hour and explained materials well. Also the marking criteria are well justified. The only thing that might catch you off guard is the amount of effort each assignment requires. Try to do them ASAP and ask for help if you are stuck somewhere. Midterm and final are  alright with a few tricky questions.

Pay close attention in lecture and you'll save yourself time later on the assignments and on the exams. Do the problems he provides in class. Geoffrey is very helpful during office hours and after lecture. While the grading scheme is not easy, he is very fair and will go over your assignments with you to show what you need to work on.

No practice exams. Exam questions really come from left field as he doesn't like to talk about exam contents or how to prepare. Concepts tested are not usually covered in lectures, but instead are an augmentation/extension of material. Take his class if you are good at critical thinking on the spot, doesn't matter if you are good at studying.
His midterm was horrible due to the fact that he never gave out materials to help us prepare for it. He got really defensive when students brought up the issues and blamed the class for everything.

I think Brad gets a lot of hate, some deserved but a lot is not. I really enjoyed his lectures. He posts half filled notes before class and you can just fill in the rest. He asks a lot of questions to the class, but treated wrong answers very brash and to the point. He also comes across as full of himself but he knows what he is talking about. 6/10

CMPT 225 is a tough class that covers a lot of algorithms that can be difficult to fully master and understand. By not providing full notes Brad's class was always packed with people asking questions and learning from the animated in class slides. Tough assignments but I learned a lot, great prof.

Very tough class, found the assignments helpful in terms of learning various algorithms that I know will be relevant to the field and lecture during most of the year were good and interactive. Wish lectures were provided filled in, but overall learned a lot.

A good CS prof that cares about everyone understanding the concept at hand before moving on to the next one.  Always available after class and does not mind spending time in class answering questions to make sure everyone understands what is going on. Also can get the class engaged in the lecture by asking questions.

I was in the other section of CMPT 225; the content was collaborative so I felt I should review Brad. His marked materials are representative of the content you're expected to know. His notes I've seen are a little sparse. He is a tough grader, but a good lecturer. He can be tough on his students, but it gets results. Work hard and you can do well.

Brad only posts partially filled in lecture slides. It's expected that you fill them in as he talks. This didn't work for me - it made learning the concepts tougher. Ignore the charges of racism in one that review, they are completed unfounded from what I saw. Nice guy, tough prof, tough course. Your results may vary.

The homework and exams were very fair in Brad's class. My main critique for Brad is that there was no sample exams/practice questions provided to us before the exams. This made gauging/testing my knowledge of the material difficult going into the exam. But there's always more I could've done and everyone was in the same boat so can't be mad.

I don't know what the negative reviews are about, Computing Science is MEANT to be hard and challenging. Brad Genuinely gives some of the best lectures and the clearest assignments I have ever seen. His exams don't focus on memorizing but applying concepts, and he aways made special effort to be kind and respectful in class. Brad is a gem at SFU.

Lectures are fantastic and it really seems like he wants you to understand the material but he comes off as quite rude and arrogant. Gets mad when nobody replies to his questions but gives condescending responses when students give wrong answers. Told us to study harder after our midterm which averaged 45%. No completed notes so be ready to copy.

Good job teaching overall, his lectures are well prepared, though it's kind of annoying spending money to print skeleton lecture notes, since he doesn't provide filled ones and I don't have a tablet. Can be condescending which makes asking questions harder, and doesn't provide much exam prep material. Though, he's not a bad guy, but pretty strict.

PROS: clear explanations of concepts. CONS: arrogant/condescending, does not foster a learning environment, blames students for bad exam marks, rejects feedback, no practice material at all for exams, DOES NOT POST FULL LECTURE SLIDES - they are partially filled out but makes reviewing harder and missing class is devastating.

Fantastic lecturer, explains concepts in great simple terms and he is tough but really knows how to make his class learn. He is a little judgemental if you answer wrong or ask a question he considers stupid, but overall he makes an effort to make everyone learn. If can take a class with him do it, but get ready to work for you grade.

Unflexible teacher. Got midterm back w/ 46% avg and he kept being hostile and complaining for 20mins about how it wasn't his fault and that he isnt going to change anything. Very determined to not give complete lecture notes, even though students said it would be beneficial.

Dont take this professor if you dont want to spend your entire two days on assignments. 4th assignment worst (5 days spent without any credit as it did not work properly and class average for that assignment was 16%)

His lectures are easy to understand but his exams and assignments are really tricky. Sometimes you will be confused whether you are studying a 300-level course. Although I passed, I decided to retake the 225 but not his.
This guy is drama king on his lecture but nobody go along with him.

He is a good instructor as he provides all the things that you need to know in his lectures. His assignments are pretty long and difficult and even if you get the right solution, you can still loose a lot of marks because of the incorrect output format. His quizzes were challenging but some were not. Both midterms and final were very fair.
The best prof in SFU!! His assignments and quizzes are free mark. Final is super easy

One of the most easy cmpt prof sfu. He post all the codes in the class so we do not need to copy the code from the class. He tells everything what will be on the exam so you just need to study what he asked to study. Midterm average was 90% and Final average was 83% which got curved up. Take him for GPA booster!! The class average is B+.

Probably one of the most anti student profs I've ever seen. Won't post notes, no sample exam questions, no exam keys, no partial marks. On top of the extremely time consuming assignments he gave completely different lab quizzes to different lab groups. One group had an average of 75, the other 14. He didn't really scale the class, average was a C.
he is way too hard of a marker, avoid this class.

Most students know data structure&&algorithm is important because most interviews ask question about them. However, do you think if you get A in Bart's cmpt225 may pass work level interview? Absolutely not because you never practice interview question but Bart taught some macm201, cmpt295 and 307 skills in 225, which makes the course fairly tough

Well... I do think a portion of us are being picky to give unreasonable evaluations to Brad. Fairly say, Brad's exam and assignment are not THAT hard as long as you spend enough time. Data structure is so important and many students do not realize that. Make effort, discover and be chary in exams. You will be good and appreciate Brad in future.

For me, Brad Bart was extremely tough. He lectures well, but when it comes to the course material that you get graded on, things get a little sad. His Lab Quizzes are unreasonable (Below 40% average). For his assignments, slightly incorrect outputs often times amount to a zero mark. Exam questions come out of left field and are hard to prep for.

When take his course. Remind urself: do u wanna lower ur GPA, if yes then take it. His lecture seems clear but it doesn't help u know how to do questions on lab quiz and assignments which are depend on random luck. Usually his exam r really trick. Get familiar with lecture notes are not enough. Any teacher is better than him, for ur GPA trust me.

Brad is a great instructor that genuinely cares about his students learning the material he teaches in clasd. He always encourages questions during lectures. Extension on some assignments would have been an asset, particularly the one during the week of his midterm, but if you understand concepts, his exams are OK

Took cmpt225 with him makes the course become fairly tough course. Many exam questions key never appear in his 30 lectures, especially title of some questions is Data Structures and Algorithms that is CMPT307 not 225! His assignment and quiz are also difficult to get mark, even if you get correct output

Final exam is extremely hard. He only taught BST, AVL, B - tree ... and never teaches a rooted tree which node has 0  n children but in final exam, we need to write a recursion function to compute sum of all node value of the rooted tree.

Brad Bart is a no nonsense teacher. Lectures slides tend to be very compact and to the point. He is also not afraid to spend 10 minutes on one slide if need be. Expects you to do a lot of deep thinking about course material within the lecture. Success in this class is found from learning the concepts rather than memorizing the code.

Good at teaching, exams and assignments are extremely unrelated. No indication on what to study for the exams. Concepts are taught in a very abstract fashion and nothing was applied to code after Lecture 19. (There was a total of 30 lectures). Assignment grading is very tough and he gave a ridiculously difficult assignment during exam week. Meh

Maybe this professor is good at teaching and he has nice lectures. But he will make this 3-credit course become a 6-credit course. Doing assignment carefully is very important since his TA will give you 0 if your code can not pass the test, even though you just forget output one space. Unfair lab quiz is also a problem. Good Luck!

Effort can not help you get a good grade. In his assignment, guess what he think is more important than reading question since most of test cases do not show, you must guess. In his lab quiz, luck is more important than your preparation since you may meet an easy question or not but he thinks all of them are same difficulty

Unfair lab quiz: in each section, level of difficulty of test question is obvious different. He only guessed if it is easy or not, never consider about students' feeling. Unfair assignment grading: students who pay much effort to got correct output with missing negligible will receive 0 mark like doing nothing on coding. He Never Replies Emails
Very funny and approachable professor but doesn't mind giving out 0's. His lectures aren't helpful and the assignments are difficult. Avoid if you can.

In lecture, Bart will that he owes us minutes of time for ending lecture a few mins late. In actuality, he owes everyone several hours of time, because he makes the paper portion of assignments due in the morning before lecture starts. This means that students have to arrive at campus early, hand in their assignment, and then waste time doing jack.

Brad Bart is a good professor. He will not cradle, or baby you and will have very reasonable expectations aimed to push you as a student. I feel these are qualities a university prof should have. When you take year 3-4 classes which assume you're a good programmer, you will think back and thank him for pushing you. Take his class.

I do not really know what I can say..just avoid him at all the cost unless you are one of those 4.0 GPA computing science students who loves to spent hours and hours on his stuff. The course is hard, but the thing i really hated was his personality not the course. He always wants to say " I am the best" He thinks he is funny but not even clos

I tok CMPT 120 /w Bart earlier & I thought he was a good prof 4 that course. 4 some reason coming around this year & recently he's turned into a bad prof. I found his lectures for CMPT 225 2 b unrelated 2 the material, & often u end up learning c++ by urself. so bad he had 2 bring in da dept. advisor 2 discuss /w da class abt the low avg on exams.

I don`t want to see him ever again in my life. Don`t take the course with him unless you are one of those genius computing science students who loves to spend hours and hours for just one of his assignments. He does not scale at all. I wonder how many people got A+ and how many failed.

Last term I made the mistake of taking a course with brad. He is such a bad prof, does not know what he is talking about and his assignments are very long and hard. His marking isn't fair, he will make every effort to make your life miserable. DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE WITH HIM

Brad is a humongous dork and enhances his lectures with his own sense of humour. Exams are fair, assignments are relevant to what's being learned. He is also friendly and helpful if you ask him questions during his office hours. Ask a stupid question and he'll gladly point it out to everyone.

I got a C+, he is the reason I am not able to transfer into CMPT. that semester I took only CMPT 225, the quizzes were different from the assignments. I viewed my examed after it was marked and found several mistakes, got a 7% increase.

Seems like a nice guy but he can't teach. Just reads off the slides. Seems to have no idea how to use a computer. Assignments were basically free marks. Exams were okay. If you do better on the final than any / all of 3 the "quizzes", your final exam mark replaces those.

His lecture is useless and seldom reply email. It is CMPT225 but 50% of the content I felt like CMPT125. It is better to just reading the book and study at home. His quizzes are very boring (one question testing induction proof) and lack of marking standard. The average of quiz is about 60%. Just go for another professor...

I attended all his lectures and I'm still not sure what he's doing in any of those. It's like he's never used a computer before. He took the slides from someone else but didn't take the coloured version and then just read them. Assignments don't help you understand the course at all but very easy. Quizzes and Exams are extremely long.

Worthless lectures. Read the slides and textbook. The assignments are a free 100%, and basically pads up the class average. I suppose the quizzes and final were fair enough. The content itself could be interesting, but the instructor is just not good at introducing and explaining any of these concepts.
very hard prof.
if you want to learn something, don't take this prof.

Quizzes are simple. TAs were not hard markers. Answered a question completely wrong and still got 60% on it. Lectures and quiz questions sometimes do not make sense (Ramesh is not native English speaker). Lights are turned off during lectures. Final exam was difficult. Avoid if you want to learn, take if you want an easy A.
His quizzes and tests are too easy, not challenging.

lectures are slow. given HW which wont be marked from textbook, and saying the quiz will be different. does not give any sample quiz. youtube and the textbook have taught me more then this prof. additionally, he makes data structures boring.
He is just the best prof in SFU CS.
One of the best compsci profs I've encountered. Really friendly, explains topics clearly, and exams were fair. Do the work and you'll do fine.

He is a good prof but not for a CMPT course. He teaches the course like it is a social science course(He wastes too much time on slides than necessary but slides have all the knowledge you need to pass.) so attendance is not needed. Assignments took most of the grade(%60) so it is less stressful. You need to know pre-reqs because he uses them.

Assignments and exams were pretty fair and related to course material. Focused more on theory and pseudocode than actual coding which is good imo since a data structures & algorithms class should try to be language agnostic. Only major cons were posting assignments/study guides late and slow marking on assignments. Good for 1st time teaching 225.

He has a different approach to teaching computing. His assignments have a coding part and written part. Midterm and final had all written questions,mostly about coming up with algorithms, sometimes pseudocode. I liked the idea of testing us heavily on algorithms because you learn a lot of coding in other classes anyway. Slides were self-explanatory

This class in a nutshell: posts study guide Wednesday, posts practice exam Thursday, FINAL EXAM FRIDAY. He literally reads of the slides and if you're kind of new to coding have fun because he does not show any examples of how to code things. He'll give you the algorithms for some functions but you're going to have to learn the rest yourself.

Unorganized, read only from slides, didn't do any examples with class, didn't teach code other than 1st few days. Almost always away when needing to meet. Homework vague marked slowly with little feedback. Forgot to give, needed code for assignment few hours before, deadline. Gave 2 weeks for each assignment for 1st half, 2nd half was given 1 week.

He just reads the lecture slides and never does any kind of coding practice in class. His lecture slides also looks like the complex introduction of the topics that seems that he's reviewing the stuff in his 700 level cmpt classes. The assignments are totally vague. If you actually want to learn then don't take his class.

Seems extremely unorganized. Lectures often make simple concepts seem confusing. Assignments, lectures, and midterms could be mistaken for 3 different courses. Does not really teach material, instead chooses to solve problems in his head and describe his thoughts (basically trying to teach math strictly verbally)

Always busy to actually do said office hours. Unorganized with giving assignments, teaching you to finish said assignments. Funny, nice guy. Wait till a few hours before assignment was due to tell us that his code he gave us to do the assignment was faulty/incomplete. Didn't actually teach how to apply code to problems. was 1st time teaching class

He cares about the students and tries to give them the best he can. If you have any difficulties with his course, go to his office hours. He tries to give a full understanding of the ppt slides. At first, I won't guarantee whether you will like him or not but in the end, you won't regret taking his lecture as a lot of the students in my class did.

Nicest, kindest professor you will ever meet, Such a great guy, and always so helpful and understanding, even for assignement extensions, etc. Good lectures too, although majority of the course was just set by the John Edgar, midtern and exam were fair.
Kindest and most helpful CS prof I've had yet.
Such a great guy.... def recommend him

David is a good prof, some explanations are confusing (mostly cuz of the slides). He does his best to help. The exams were quite challenging although I understand he didn't write them. Assignments are really long and difficult. Most took 10-20 hr and there's 5. 50% final so gotta lock in for it. Final grading scheme / scaling very fair overall!
He just good

This guy is very detailed. You know exactly what to study; he even explains the code implementations. He has lecture recordings from day 1 and is genuinely an awesome guy.
He has a strong accent thogh, but it works in your favor. keeps you awake as he tries to be funny. 
in my opinion, the most goated 200 level course prof.

A really good professor, answers my questions and explains it really well so that I can understand it. He explains the slides while also giving us examples so that we understand what the slides are telling us. If he doesn't really understand what are the slides are saying, he will put the explanation in the announcement later in the day on canvas.

David is one of the BEST profs I've had. His lectures are amazing and very interesting. He is a really nice person and responds to all email fast. His exam study instructions are very clear and helpful.
Like the other commen said was help back my John's slides. However David is an amazing person and really easy to talk too. Replies to emails very quickly, some would say to quickly!

Goated prof, incredibly approachable, gives great feedback, and very helpful and understanding. Unfortunately, he was being held back by the Burnaby section's lecture and exam materials which were abysmal in quality and difficulty. If it weren't for David's input, I would have failed.

He's lecture is clear. It is important to get used to his accent. He is willing to help students. 
However, he always mark tests very late. For the midterm he released the grade after the course drop date(almost 3weeks after the test). There are plenty of online sources for this course. So the grade part is important when taking it in university.
THE GOATTTTTTTTTTTTTT 🐐 Lectures are easy to follow and he gives advice on how to perform well in class. Love this guy so much.

Dr. Chou is a great teacher, with clear instructions and very intuitive explanations;however Some of the tests are very long and need to be done very fast. Read the textbook, understand the homework completely, and really try to understand the structures and you will have an easy A+
VERY HARD assignments/exams, but VERY INTERESTING guy!
Great prof. Responds to emails like lightning. The subject isn't all that easy though.

way his class is designed.. people who are getting higher marks will keep getting even higher because most of the bonus are impossible for normal people. He is a great guy though.. very helpful when you ask him questions and he's only like 23! You really learn in his class. I really hope he scales the grades though.. that would make him my fav prof
Really hard final exam. Have some pity on students - After all they are human beings. I beg you to scale the grade marks.
Very nice prof...extremely hard, but teaches a lot. Expects a lot from students. Overall, my grades are low, but he is very likeable.
Pretty tough syllabus but he does give lots of quizzes so you have a chance at pulling your grades up.

Overall, he is a good prof and teaches well in the class. He is very helpful and is available for extra office hours. Assignments and midterm was hard. Well, I hope he was going to curve the final grade of the class b/c barcharts show that around half of the class is failing the midterm, and I am wondering how they are going to get a grade of C & <

he was good for being a TA, but as an instructor, he might be tough (or very tough) for some students. Very helpful tho. MT and quiz are hard...need to write lots of explanation ... maybe i can't get used to his teaching style, coz he makes me really hate comp sci :(

His labs and assignments are extremely long, and often confusing. Don't worry thou, for he answers all your questions almost instantly if you email him, and he gives tons of examples and explainations to help you understand. He gives in-class quizzes to help you boost mark. Lecture notes were awesome. (animated!) And he has a great sense of humor.

tough but fair. this class requires lots of hard work and the assignments demand a lot. but really whats the point in going to university if there is no challenge. This prof tells it like it is. Very thorough in his explanations and provides helpful feedback. Overall good prof.

He is extremely helpful, with quick email responses and easy access in person (he is always at his office). he is also quite clear, always with diagrams. The guy himself is awesome. His tests, labs, and assignments are hard, but fair. If you have trouble, just talk to him to get the problems sorted out.

Assignments and labs are vigorous and extremely challenging for the student comin out of CMPT125. He replies quickly w lot of info when u email him. Mt was HARD, and instead of scaling, he gives HARD inclass quizzes that lets u raise ur mark if you get all the questions correct. No review classes to help w/ MT. lab attendance not mandatory.

Really great teacher with lots of examples.  Class is never too dull.  Would take any other class from him, even if wasn't all that interested in the subject because of how he can make boring stuff more interesting.
Great availability (e-mail, extra appointments, ...). Willing to help. Assignments and labs are a bit long but challenging. Lots of feedback!
Hate this guy! Won't scale even though most of the class failed the midterm.. Horrible prof, inconsiderate of student?s opinion.

He says he's fair and a true gem. He tries to be funny but you won't laugh when you see your grade. If you don't have the exact expected output be ready to get 0. It's pass or fail. Quoting him "excels in hardship". Be ready to be forged by the trial by FIRE.

Johns course was pretty difficult but you learn alot from it, the exams were very legthy but were reasonable difficulty wise, same for assignments. What I like about John, is that hes actually really nice, and accessible outside of class, not just for questions, but other things, since hes a member of the undergrad chair for comp sci.

John's a really nice professor, if you actually talk to him about assignments or grading, he is usually fairly generous, his lectures were boring, but they were also really informative, quizzes and assignments were pretty fair, mostly adt implementations. Midterm and final both fair difficulty wise, but too long. TA's were really harsh markers tbh.

His lectures are really boring and the midterm was pretty bad, BUT the assignments, quizzes and final were all extremely fair. Considering that the midterm was only worth 15%, the class overall wasn't difficult. He's a nice guy too and generally pretty forgiving in my experience
Lost his will to teach about 10 years ago. Loves reading slides and making Starcraft references as much as possible. Highly recommend this class for a good nap at 8:30am.

The class itself is easy, it just has a pretty high workload. John's lectures were alright, I found that I often had to go through the recordings to connect the concepts, and this took hours. But the quizzes aren't hard, the final was fair too.

Edgar's a solid prof, fair assignments (basic ADT implementations), weekly quizzes are pretty easy, and final was straightforward. The midterm was a bit tough, but only worth a small portion of the grade, and he did scale a bit at the end. Solid choice for this course, gives a good foundation.

Pretty big yapper. Lectures are a little boring but informative. Really try your best to understand the material. Tests are just leetcode easy so you should be doing leetcode as much as possible. Assignments are were pretty easy and just ADT implementations.

The final was very fair and representative of the material and thoroughly tested your understanding. It was comprehensive yet balanced, allowing us to demonstrate our understanding and apply our knowledge meaningfully.

Professor John Edgar is a great professor. Contents on his slides are clear and strightly related to assignment/mid-term/final. No assignments or quiz are off the scope. Go start writing some C++ code before taking this course (if you don't, you will also be fine). PS: Final wieghts 50%!!!!!!!

John Edgar is an alright prof. He explains the concepts well but is pretty dull most of the time, lectures are kinda boring. Class difficulty was ok but TAs are very harsh on assignment grading. Also, the Canvas quizzes are false hope in regards to test difficulty, the tests are much harder. Also, final exam worth 50%, ouch

CMPT225 is a hard LD course, so many people will bash him for harsh exams; he was decent/fair. Exams had tricky MCQ, but doable written. Quizzes from slides, assignments were fairly straightforward. Quiet/monotone during lecture but provided great insights to material. Strongly suggest showing up to class to grasp a better understanding of DSA.
John's a chill guy.

You know, I actually really liked John as a prof, despite not liking him all that much at first. His midterm was very difficult, but only worth 15%. The assignments, quizzes, and final were all very fair and worth most of the grade. His lectures were enthusiastic and he often went on funny tangents in class lol. Very responsive to emails too

Lectures are a little boring but are recorded and slides decent. You will have to learn a good bit of implementation on your own but thats expected. Assignments (for the most part) and quizzes are fair. Prof is quite nice and replies to emails quickly. Only issue is no sample exams which made studying for them really hard.

Honestly John is a really enjoyable lecturer and in the end his grading was quite fair. The midterm was pretty tough but as it was only 15% compared to a 50% final, so it's not that hard to bounce back. Assignments were a lot of work which is a given considering the complexity of the topic. Be prepared to do a lot of coding practice.

grading criteria is clear, and he is very organized, but thats about it. HORRIBLE exams and an extremely tough grader! Quiz questions rarely even show up on actual exam material, Assignments are extremely difficult and will leave u to learn concepts that he hasn't even gone over in class with the same difficulty, he sucks, better luck next time ig

John is a great professor, he definitely likes to go on tangents though during lecture. I found his assignments and quizzes easy. His exams are fair but without example examinations can leave a lot students putting time into the wrong elements of the material. John is very approachable and ensures that grade corrections are addressed.
50% final with insanely low avg, slides are confusing af. Had to learn on my own
Good lectures, good assignments, final was very fair, midterm was bad, but other than that he was great. His grading scheme sucked, that's why I gave a 4 not a 5

His multiple choice questions on the actual exam are way more difficult than the quiz questions he assigns. He claims they're of similar difficulty, but that is not true at all. the final exam being worth 50% of your grade means no matter how well you've done throughout the semester, one exam ends up deciding whether you pass or fail.
Very vague about the final, and gives no practice leading up to the final- when students ask questions, he is very unhelpful. Do not recommend, you won't learn much.

His lecture slides are okay, but the lectures are a bit dull—he needs to make them more engaging and stop reading off slides. The tests are very hard and not really related to the material. The class average was 42%, John made the test unnecessarily long for the time given. Grind out the leetcode for this class and understand the data structures.

I would say that John is very nice and approachable, and does a decent job explaining most concepts. His assignments are mostly fair and based on the data structures we learned in class. His midterm was killer tho, but other than that, it's a good experience. Many will complain, but that's just 225, it's a hard class.

His lectures are actually pretty good, and his weekly quizzes are very fair. The assignments are also not too bad, but require some problem solving. One major con is that his midterm was way too long, causing many people to do poorly. He's approachable outside of class and during office hours.

I like the course, assignments are fun(to me) and lectures are good. But, I wish he was more invested in our success and kinder. The talk he gave us after the midterm made it seem like our fault and he basically spent the whole time trying to defend himself saying that the midterm was reasonable when it clearly was not considering everyone failed.
He couldn't do his own midterm in class, something is clearly not right with him. I BEG YOU, PLEASE AVOID:

He just yaps at lectures and tries to avoid the disappointment that is his midterm, it's like the elephant in the room, but he refuses to talk about how bad it is. His assignments and midterms suck, not a good professor tbh I'd rather take Janice.

John Edgar is an expert at making students burn out. Avoid at all costs. His assignments are way too time consuming for what little weight they contribute. Majority of people scored below 50% on the midterm. Pretty bad overall

Lectures, slides and quizzes make you think the class is easy. The assignments are terrible and are way harder + longer than they need to be. They are WAY too hard comapred to what he teaches. Some midterm question have nothing to do what he teaches and it was way longer than it shouldve been. No practice midterm made this a lot worse.

Our midterm average was brutal compared to other years—42% versus 80%, solely because of John. Please, AVOID this professor. There is no practice midterm, which is pretty unrelated to the lecture slides. Overall, the slides are pretty useless and only discuss the basics. Assignments are also complicated with few resources. AVOID!

Solid prof. Lectures are enthusiastic, he's nice and funny. His assignments are fair and doable, but require some problem solving skills. Weekly Canvas quizzes are quite straightforward and good practice. His midterm was really difficult though, mainly due to time constraints. Be prepared to write quickly. Nonetheless, he's decent.

Midterm was super unfair, completely unrelated to most of the lectures and material + 50 minutes for 15mcq and 2 hard written answers is just unfair. In addition, a lot of the assignments are unrelated to the material, and pretty hard with little guidance. John is nice, but that is pretty much the only pro.

John edgar's midterm was very unreasonable. Considering we had no cheatsheet, no sample paper and tough coding questions which require you to think critically, I would not recommend John to anybody. I know I failed miserably even though i studied quite a lot. 15 mcqs + 2 difficult coding problems in 50 minutes is unfair.

Pros: Nice guy, cracks a few jokes during lectures. Has weekly quizzes on Canvas that are pretty fair (if you are keeping up, you should get at least 7/10). Assignments are pretty fair and requirements are well-organized.


Cons: Midterm was just BAD. 10 page exam in 50 mins. 15 theory heavy MCQ (trick questions) and HARD written section.

John is a nice guy. But good god he needs to start learning how to use a microphone properly. You literally can't hear him if you are at any row other than the front few. His exams are also the dumbest thing ever - way too long and hard for a 50 minute exam. Reads off of slides during lecture in the most monotonous voice. AVOID!!

Honestly he was fine professor I thought, but his midterm was so far beyond unreasonable I'm genuinely shocked. Everyone I've talked to has said it was extremely hard and not proportional at all to lectures and assignments. There was so much on there that we didn't learn and had no idea what to study.

I would say he doesn't even care if you are listening to him or not. His mic is always turned off or doesn't work for some reason. He doesn't go much in depth compared to how difficult his exams and assignments are.

Excels at teaching concepts simply, makes everything accessible online, and has weekly quizzes that are useful to track your progress in the class. Midterm was straightforward however the final was unfortunately all multiple choice due to the TA strike. Overall a great prof though, one of the best Ive had so far no doubt.

Low class averages on quizzes, many times a failing average. Average on the midterm was a fail, 8 pages in 50 minutes. If you went wrong on assignments it says you failed a test but does not specify how and where you went wrong so you can't improve your programming later on.

John's lectures notes are already filled up; ready for you to write down anything you think is important. If you have time, pre-read the lecture material the day before class. Workload for me was about 12 - 15 hr/week (+/- 3 hr), so YMMV. Exams are fair. Just make sure you understand all the algorithms and can draw out their diagrams on paper.
One of the best profs I had in SFU. Although the course had lots of stuff to do almost every week like quizzes and exercises but it was fun learning from his lectures.

Good choice for 225. Failed my first attempt w/ another prof. John is better than that other prof. Responds quickly when you need clarification on asmt, even on weekends! Before John, none of my 225 asmt ever compiled. My prog. skills improved after taking his class :) Join the CSSS discord group, students there are helpful when you're stuck.

He is a cheerful professor but he gives a lot of work. His weekly quizzes were hard with a low average and assignments require a ton of work. His final was confusing for me and he doesn't teach much. You must be fluent in c++ before taking this class with him. I DO NOT recommend this class with him. It was a nightmare for me.

John is a solid option for CMPT 225. Responds quickly to questions, has fair assignments, and is a chill/funny guy. Weekly quizzes on the hard side sometimes, but are good for reinforcing concepts. Overall had a good experience - John did very well in the transition to online learning. Would take again!

John is one of those profs with which you get out what you put in. Weekly quizzes and exercises force you to be up to date with the material, which was great for a chronic procrastinator like me. Assignments are long and often difficult, but very thoroughly explained and fair (Start them early). Course was also overall really well-organized.

Let me start off by saying people did say Edgar was a good prof and he was difficult. But this class was just incredibly hard. Averages on quizzes were roughly 8/15. Exercises were not that hard but some were difficult. The first 2 assignments were easy. The red black tree took me 5 days to implement. Average was low on it. Incredibly high workload

His exercises are way to hard and time consuming. The quizzes we barely have time to finish and the average comes back to be 9/15. Like Edgar really needs to reconsider his grading and tests. Assignments arent bad. Lecture heavy and harsh grader for sure. I dont recommend taking a class with him

Took Cmpt 225 with him and it was actual hell. He had weekly quizzes that had close to failing averages every single week not to mention the insane time constraints. The assignments that you get from this class will take you at least a few days of grinding if you are comfortable with c++. Start them asap and make sure you test extensively

Doesnt teach the class. Most of the grading was for quizzes assignments and exercises. They were very time consuming. Took weeks for me as they seemed easy but werent. This class has a take home final not worth much but it was sort of difficult. The overall class is challenging if you arent on top of your c++ skills.

Edgar has many flaws in his teaching. Incredibly time consuming assignments (takes days) to his quizzes that are always on the new topic he teaches. You must keep up and understand everything of c++. Binary search trees, hash tables etc. If you didnt learn this in 125 or dont know much, dont take it yet. You will fail.

Crazy amount of hours put into a few assignments. He makes sure that if you want to take this class, you need to put in the work. Quizzes are a tad difficult as if you fall behind you will fail them for sure. You NEED to know c++ fluently before this class. Make sure if you can take it later with someone else, DO IT.

Quizzes every week. Assignments that will take many days. Final exam was a tad tough. Entirely this prof made this course much harder than its supposed to be. If you want to take CMPT 225, take it when hes not the prof. You will do better and have more fun. Edgar is a massive No. read the other reviews below and youll know what I mean.

Horrible prof. Will give u a 0 for the smallest mistake. Make sure to work on the assignments early, took me 4-5 days to complete them. The quizzes were annoying as you needed to keep up with all the material every week. He just read the notes , wasnt really teaching. Take it with a diff prof.

Harsh marker. I added an extra a in my name and it gave a compiling error and got 0. This isnt where u can email Edgar and say oh I only forgot this. U get 0 no matter what. Extremely high workload. Keep up ! Start weeks before as it will take that long to do. Those who know c++ should take 2-3 days to finish them.

Very very harsh grader. Lots of work. Lots lots of work. If you have a tight schedule, I recommend taking only 2 other classes with this one. The workload is a 5/5 for sure. Its like cmpt 125+127 all in one. Edgar doesnt even provide much details on the assignments in c++. He expects u to know it. MAKE SURE TO GO OVER UR C++!!!

Way to many quizzes. Need to stay on top as there is a quiz every week. Many assignments which will take 20+ hours for those who know there stuff. Maybe 35+ for those who dont know c++. Make sure if you take this class, that u always ask questions as he doesnt clarify anything. And know theres a lot of work.

Lots of work. Get ready to learn the advanced algorithms of hash tables. If you are not 100% on top of C++, dont take this class. He doesnt go over it and our first assignment was creating a game with binary trees.

I learned a lot from this class! The exercises and assignments were straight forward and exams only being worth 30% made things less stressful. Be careful of the marking policies though. You can get a 0 over a typo in your filename causing a compiler error.

I really liked the structure of the class, you watch the video lectures, and complete a weekly quiz/exercise, which helped with the understanding of the content. The assignments were also really straightforward and clear. Some of the material was already taught in CMPT 125, but I felt like he explained the concepts better..

I was not even moderately prepared for his expectations. Each weekend had a quiz and a HARD exercise that you had to complete. His assignments are NOVEL length long and take forever. You basically have to interview him during office hours. Marking is dependent on TA, but never reconsidered by John. Red black trees still haunt my dreams.

I have had him for CMPT 354 and CMPT 225 with 354 being online. If you are good at CMPT and enjoy learning about the more niche parts of the course, you'll love it. However if you are only mediocre at it, you'll have an exponentially harder time compare to other profs. His exams and assignments really wordy/tricky with lots of trick questions.

He is the best professor that I've had so far at SFU. He is really clear about tasks you have to do each week, and also really helpful and accessible during the whole semester. We had an online class this semester and I hope I can take more classes with him in the future.

Taking CMPT 225 online with him. Really good professor. The lectures are well organized and clear. There's a short quiz and exercise each week, which covers the basic concept of the course materials and can be really good practice. Keep up with the course materials and you are good to go! Highly recommended.

Requirements of each of his assiments like a short story. I feel like I read a novel. It is easy to miss something. I also want to say he should pay more attention to each line of students' codes rather than file's name. You can get zero easily because of adding library even the whole code is fine.

I don't know there wasn't anything special from this prof, he was kind of all over the place and when you would ask him questions he would never give a clear answer and leave you more confused. No extra practice is available so it's hard what to expect is examined.

Really nice professor overall, he's always willing to help through emails and in person. Lectures can be a bit dry but if you pay attention he explains everything well and can be funny. Labs are non mandatory, assignments are big but doable if you start early.

His lecture is amazing with perfect-organized slides. He shows everything step by step using a nice example(personly think an example is much more helpful than theorem), so you could understand even if you have no base.

You can tell by the way he presents himself in class and speaks with enthusiasm that he loves what he does. His method of delivering lectures is phenomenal and encourages questions in order to be crystal clear. His jokes lighten up the class and maintains a very welcoming atmosphere. I wish he taught every CMPT class offered at burnaby and surrey!

Easy final exam (the average was crazzzyyy high). His posted notes covered everything on the exams. Assignment were straightforward. Labs were never for any marks, yay! Would totally like to have this guy again.
Great Prof! His lectures are excellent.

He is very nice and funny person. keeps the lectures not boring. study the lectures and assignments for midterms and finals. Final is easier than midterm. He SCALES alot and teaches well. 225 is a hard course so make sure you take it with John Edgar.

He has interest in the course. Helps students, read his slides thoroughly if you want to get an A+. His slides are easy to understand but can be misleading if you dont attend the lectures. For midterms, many questions with little time to answer so start with those that you know. Assignments take so much time to complete, so start early.

In all my four years at SFU, John Edgar is honestly the BEST teacher of any class I've ever taken. He has a genuine interest in the subject, a great sense of humour and his lectures are extremely helpful. I was abysmal at all things computer-science, and now it all makes perfect sense. Do yourself a favour and take his a class with John Edgar.

Amazing Prof...Very funny guy..will keep you interested by making fun of him self and bringing in mods of games he has coded. Very Helpful and material is not too tough...one of the best cmpt courses i have taken for sure
The man, even though he screws up, makes fun of the fact he screwed up and keeps going. got to enjoy it!
